photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/77627.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first stuffing! The broth amount and bread consistency are key to the success of this recipe. We went to a local Oregon bakery and picked up loaves of just baked artisan and multi-grain breads and sliced into cubes then baked at 250 for 25 minutes (checking frequently).  The hearty, chewy texture of the bread was very successful with this recipe as it did not become soggy during the cooking process.  We added 2.5 cups of stock (just enough to moisten) and a pound of crumbled, cooked sage sausage.  I did stir it after the first hour in the pot and then occasionally during the cooking time.  This was necessary as the stuffing becomes very brown on the bottom.  I agree that the high setting may not be needed since all the crock pot process is doing is re-incorporating the bread with the stock and other flavors.  Many of the 17 folks at our dinner were interested in how this recipe would turn out and we were all pleased with the results.

text:
I have always made box stuffing.  This was my first attempt at "homemade" stuffing and my husband couldn't stop raving about it!
Changes I made were:
*Using bagged stuffing, about 1 &1/2 bags.
*I didn't measure my chicken broth.  I got consistancy I was looking for like when I make boxed stuffing. 
*My seasoning was 2 tsp of poultry seasoning, instead of all the other stuff.
Perfect way to free up some room in your oven!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely perfect for our Thanksgiving meal (9 people, half of whom are EXTREMELY picky eaters) this year!  I especially loved having the extra space in my oven!

I definitely made a few tweaks to the recipe to make it more "my own."  I used a mixture of croissants and good Italian white bread that I had cubed and dried in my oven.  Plus, when I melted the butter, I added the dried herbs in with the onion/celery/mushrooms, so that the herbs would eventually be evenly distributed throughout the bread mixture.

Finally, I added the chicken broth only a little at a time.  I didn't need nearly as much broth as the recipe calls for, as my bread was a little more fresh than the original recipe uses.

All in all I highly recommend this recipe, and it will certainly be used again!

This was absolutely perfect for our Thanksgiving meal (9 people, half of whom are EXTREMELY picky eaters) this year!  I especially loved having the extra space in my oven!

I definitely made a few tweaks to the recipe to make it more "my own."  I used a mixture of croissants and good Italian white bread that I had cubed and dried in my oven. I think I will always make my stuffing in the crock pot from now on--the method was wonderful.  I varied the recipe somewhat, however, by using seasoned stuffing cubes (white and cornbread). city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this whenever i make a turkey or chicken dinner.  Its always been a hit and i've been making it for about 4 years.  I omit mushrooms and cut the veggies so tiny you can barely tell they are there.  I also can never tell how much broth i will be using until i'm done cooking it.  Sometimes I only use 2 cups and sometimes i use all of it.  I usually pour 2 cups worth in at the beginning and I check every hour to see how dry it is and I add more and give it a stir.  It prevents the outsides from getting too crusty.  Also since some family members prefer their stuffing drier than others, I'll take out some stuffing early and let the rest cook with the lid off on high for a while.  It works everytime.

text:
For Thanksgiving our family went to the desert and so I could not use the generator in our motorhome all day to do the crockpot way so instead the day before we left I cooked the veggies (omitted mushrooms), used and cooked 1 1lb. of sage flavored sausage, and made a loaf of beer bread (cubed bread and dried out in oven), let all cool and put in plastic baggies. Thanksgiving day I mixed all the pre-made ingredients with the rest of what recipe calls for (minus sage since it was in the sausage) and baked in oven.  I also poured melted butter over the top to give it that great buttery flavor. The only thing I forgot was to add the eggs, I brought them but forgot about em. Every single person that was with us complemented me on how this was the best stuffing they had ever had and it didn't even have the eggs. I am going to make this for Christmas but instead of sage sausage and I going to use linguica like someone else suggested because our family is Portuguese and linguica is Portuguese sausage.
Review:

I made this for a family turkey dinner today and I was very impressed! I did make a few minor changes by adding a tsp of savory and a little extra pepper for taste.  Also, I can see that it would be very easy to overdo the chicken broth. I didn't add very much, just enough to barely moisten the bread and any more would have made it a little too moist.  All of my family have now asked for the recipe!

text:
AMAZING!!!  i was really nervous about this b/c of the "broth factor" but it ended up PERFECT.  i used several kinds of bread to get different textures - sourdough rolls, everything bagels, and a pecan raisin bread boule.  i let the bread sit out and get stale but then also put them in a warm oven on cookie sheets over night and let them get really crunchy.  i scaled the recipe to 8 (but actually used about 7 c of bread) and used a can of broth - and everything else called for.  i stirred it frequently - every time tasting it, so i almost had no stuffing to share!  really, it was even better than i'd hoped - i can't wait to make it again for christmas!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this stuffing was great as did everyone who tried it at Thanksgiving this year. I did use some common sense and only put in about half of the chicken broth and I also added a pound of sausage I precooked and chopped. I cut back on the butter too, it seemed like it could get too greasy with all of that butter, I only cooked it for 4 hours which was plenty! 8 hours and I would have ended up with a black stuffing brick! I just kept it on low and watched it, if I felt it was getting dry I added just a touch more broth and it came out just wonderful, it is definately the best stuffing I have made in my wife/mommy years to date! I highly recommend using this recipe just use some common sense along with it.

text:
This really is the best stuffing!  I don't add quite the suggested amount of broth--it seems to get too mushy if you do.  I add about 2 cups, and it comes out perfect.  It's great because you can make it early in the day before you get too busy, and you don't have to take up space in the much used oven.  It also comes out moist every time, unlike traditional baked stuffings.

text:
This is the first time I used a crock pot to make stuffing but it was definitely a success!!  I ended up using about 2.5 cups of the broth because my family likes stuffing a little more firm/crunchy than the traditional stuffing.  To help it get drier for serving, I just took the lid of the crock pot for about 45 minutes.  My finicky uncle even had seconds!  I will absolutely use this recipe for all my holiday dinners!

text:
This was a great recipe, and very simple. I made it for an office Thanksgiving potluck, and several people said that they enjoyed it. I did make some changes from the original recipe though. Instead of 1 cup of butter (2 sticks), I only used half a cup of butter (1 stick) to cook the vegetables. I also added 1 lb of country sausage, as well as some chopped cranberries to the stuffing mix. For the bread cubes, I used the store bought ones and I did not use the entire recommended 4.5 cups of chicken broth. I added the chicken broth in small amounts as it cooked, and I ended up using a little over 3 cups. I had the dish on high for about 45 minutes, and then it cooked on low for 2.5 hours and it was ready in time for our potluck. The only change I'd make in the future is to cut down the amount of salt in the recipe, especially if adding sausage or using store bought bread cubes.

text:
I read through a lot of the reviews before making this since I was making this for Christmas dinner.  I heeded the advice about the amount of broth.  I used Martin's Cubed Potato Bread (soft, not hard) so I only poured in maybe 2-2.5 cups.  However it was still way too moist, even with the lid off the Crockpot for about 2 hours.  I was surprised that maybe only 1-2 reviewers mentioned that there was too much butter.  This was in fact the problem.  I initially thought the amount was too much but since not many people complained I added the full amount.  Honestly with this amount of butter, you probably do not need any broth!  I ended up scooping out some of the butter in the Crockpot.  The stuffing did firm up some when it cooled.  There were mixed reviews about the burnt parts - some liked it, some didn't.  The taste of the stuffing itself was excellent.  Next time, I will half or even quarter the amount of butter and probably just cook it in the oven. Edit 12-25-2017: Ok, so I accidentally bought the stuffing that was hard- a mistake due to me not being prepared and hurried. I followed this recipe, forgetting that I used the soft stuffing in the past. I needed to add more broth (about 3 cups total) and more butter (than the half I usually do). Came out fine, but really emphasizes what kind of stuffing you use and to check it every 30minutes or so.

text:
Great recipe! Super easy and makes enough to feed a crowd. I have made this the past two Thanksgivings and will be making again this week for T-Day 2015.  I use Pepperidge Farms Seasoned Bread Cubes, then I omit the other seasonings it calls far as the cubes are already seasoned.  This makes it even easier to whip together.  I also add a pound (or two.  Depends if I am on a diet that year or not! ha) of browned sage sausage.   Please keep in mind that those people that say this is too "soupy" did not follow the directions. You add the broth as needed. So, you may not need it all.  The type of bread you use and the dryness of your climate can make a difference on how much liquid is needed. I also followed another suggestion from a reviewer and placed a clean dish towel between the Crockpot and its lid to collect condensation.  Clever idea.  It worked like a charm.  Just prior to serving I added some dried cranberries. Huge hit!  Lots of flavor! I will make this every year and pass the recipe onto my kids.

text:
I don't usually like homemade stuffing, but this was excellent!  The amount of liquid you use will depend on how dry your bread is - hence the "as needed" in the ingredient list and "pour enough broth to moisten" in the directions.  It's your own fault if you ignored those details and used too much broth.  I used the pre-packaged dry bread cubes and ended up using all 4 1/2 cups.  I used 4 cups at first, and added another 1/2 cup towards the end because it looked too dry.  Remove the lid if it looks too wet.

country:

text:
I debated whether or not to risk trying a new stuffing method since that is one of the favorites on Thanksgiving Day.  So glad I did, and will never make it any other way than the slow cooker!  Used two 1lb. loaves of Italian bread, cubed and dried out for several weeks, about 16 cups. I have a Cuisinart slow cooker that sautes/browns, so sauted chopped onions and celery while mixing my bread cubes with the broth, (about 3 1/2 cups), 1/2 lb. cooked sausage, eggs, and seasonings to taste, no salt was used.  Added the veggies to the bread mixture, and threw it all in the slow cooker.  Cooked on high for 30 minutes, and low until dinner, which was about 5 hours later.  Using the towel under the lid is a necessity, and the stuffing stays so moist that even though I checked it every hour, I used very little, if any additional broth.  I've made the same recipe for 21 years, and I was told this was the best year year ever!

text:
The key to a good dressing is the preparation. Mix all the dry ingredients together with the sautéed vegies and add the chicken broth and add some whole milk/cream to it I use 3 1/2 cup chicken broth with 1 cup whole milk the night before and then cover and put in refrigerator over night. The next day mix up prior to putting into the crock pot. The flavor will be so rich.

One more thing, I take the giblets from the turkey and boil into a broth and use that as my broth (add 1 onion and 3 celery stocks with salt and pepper). the liver I dice up into small pieces and add to dressing when I put it into the crock pot.

I like my stuffing crispy.  The flavor of this is wonderful, but it was too moist for me.  Maybe it's because I dumped all of the 4 c of chicken broth in at once. It takes the longest of our dishes to make, but it's so worth it!

country:
None
text:
I have made this for Thanksgiving and Christmas the last 3 years in a row and it always turns out awesome! I'm not a big stuffing eater (my Dad is the stuffing guy), but I LOVE this stuffing! I follow the recipe except I don't measure the broth. You have to use your judgement on that. As one reviewer suggested, add a little broth at first and then you have to taste the stuffing and add more as needed. You need to check on it several times throughout the day while it is cooking to adjust the seasonings and the broth to your taste. I don't measure when I cook anyways, just adjust based on your tastes! Also, I don't turn it up to high.. I just put it on low and let it cook while I'm working on other things.

text:
I made this for Thanksgiving and it worked out well...moist and tasty.  I followed the advice of previous posters and used only 2.5 cups of broth instead of the 4.5 cups called for in the recipe.  I added one minced clove of garlic.  I used supermarket  dried bread cubes (one bag was about 6 cups) and one fresh loaf of French bread cut into cubes. I also left out the mushrooms for taste preference. It smells great while cooking and leaves the oven free for other side dishes.

text:
I decided to try this out for Thanksgiving this year and it was so great! So easy to just throw the ingredients together in the crock pot and cook it all day while you work on other dishes. I took the advice of others and added the chicken stock about 1/2 cup at a time (about every hour) and ended up only using just under 3 cups and it came out perfect. An easy recipe to modify as well, we added toasted pecans at the end - this will become my standard dish from now on!

I decided to use this recipe when I hosted my first Thanksgiving dinner in my small kitchen.  It was nice to have one less dish to make on/in the stove.  And I'm so glad I found this recipe because it was a BIG hit!  It was so moist, almost gooey, and easy to make.  I didn't add eggs as the recipe calls and honestly they are not needed.  I also made it vegetarian by using vegetable broth and veggie bouillon instead of chicken and meat eaters would never know.  It was DELICIOUS and I know the family will call for it every year.

This turned out fantastic! I used one loaf of fresh french bread at Whole Foods and it equaled 12 cups exactly. I toasted 1/2 cubes in the oven until they were lightly browned and "crunchy." I also used No-Chicken Broth in lieu of chicken broth. I did not need the full 4 cups of broth, instead only using about 3 and even that was maybe a 1/4 cup too much. Around 3 hours into cooking I removed the lid to allow some of the moisture to evaporate. Perfect!!!! Thanks for a yummy recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
I read all the reviews and I admit I was nervous to try it for the first time on Thanksgiving Day itself! However, I used my common sense when I added the broth...I didn't add all 4 1/2 c at once. I stirred it in, and since I was in the kitchen all day, I checked it (and stirred in more broth) often. I was using packaged dry bread cubes and I'm sure I wound up using at least 4 1/2 cups of broth, if not a little more. I had a 6 cup box of broth and used almost all, but not all of it. Now that I know how the broth part works, I'll just add a lot more at the beginning to save having to add more as the day goes on. As for the rest of the recipe, the seasoning was perfect and nobody seemed to miss the "baked inside the turkey" taste. I'll be making this again on Christmas and probably next Thanksgiving, too--I put the seasonings in a tupperware the night ahead and chopped the veggies, and putting it all together the next morning was so easy, it felt like cheating!

This stuffing was the best stuffing I ever had! Made it for thanksgiving, just wish I would have listened to the tip about putting the towel between the lid. Added to my recipe box and will be making again!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My mother makes an unbelievable sweet and savory bread stuffing with raisins and celery that everyone in my family goes crazy for.  Any other stuffing has very big shoes to fill.  That said, some of the guests we invited for Thanksgiving this year do not like raisins, so I decided to try this recipe rather than just omit the raisins from the regular recipe.  Boy, did this recipe deliver!  I won't say it's better than my mother's stuffing, but it sure was good -- we got a lot of compliments!    I was able to speed up the cooking process by leaving it on high in the slow cooker and then transferring it to a pan and "toasting" the top in the oven.  I think we finished cooking it it in 4 or 5 hours, including prep time.  We pureed the mushrooms in the food processor so we could have the meaty mushroom flavor without the mushroom texture -- my husband can't stand the texture of mushrooms.  Thank you for making the stuffing a big hit!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I absolutely love the idea of having the stuffing made ahead of time and out of the way of the rest of the cooking. I also despise stuffing the actual bird! So this option sounded like a great one to me.  Luckily I tried it out ahead of time. The color of the stuffing was off (dark). I think this was due to me stirring it frequently to keep it from burning. The flavor was okay, not fabulous however. I used seasoned bread cubes since that is all that they had at the store I went to. I think this would be much better with plain bread cubes. And I will cut way down on the cooking time in the future (like 2-3 hours max). And, like others, I used less than half of the broth. Overall good recipe, just need to adjust it to my preferences. Edit: Made this again for Thanksgiving. This time I stirred it very little. I only cooked it about 3 hours and it was perfect. I added turkey drippings to it right before serving. Yum!

Review:

dateLastModified:
2009-12-30T22:25:01.447
helpfulCount:

userID:
4127723
Display Name:
Adam
isPro:
False

22
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4505033.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
People are still begging me to make this stuffing again, which I tried for the first time on Thanksgiving. I used a day old loaf of bread from my bread machine (Bread Machine Challah I on this site), toasted up the cubes in the oven for a few minutes and put it all in the slow cooker. There's no need to dirty a mixing bowl, just do the mixing in the cooker. Who needs more dishes to wash, especially on Thanksgiving? I eyeballed the broth, but probably ended up using about 2 cups. You can always add a little more toward the end if it looks too crunchy, but adding more bread is not as effective, especially if you didn't set any aside. Honestly though, just look at it while you add the broth and stop when it looks like the bread has absorbed a decent amount. Check on it and add broth periodically if you need to. Taste it an hour or so before serving and do the final adjustments. And try not to eat the whole batch.

text:
As previous reviews stated, be very carefull with adding the broth or you will end up with a soupy mess. I added only about a cup of broth and it was more then enough. Used fresh white bread which may have been the difference. Do not overcook & keep stirring the pot occassionally. Everyone raved about the stuffing- great flavour and texture. This recipe is a keeper.

text:
This was really good. I made it for Thanksgiving to save on oven room. It was so low maintenance. I started with half of the chicken broth recommended based on other reviews saying it was too moist. However, by the end, I probably added about the amount that the recipe stated and it was perfectly moist. I also used fresh herbs because I had them. And for those afraid of putting mushrooms in like I was, (based on some people not liking mushrooms)...you couldn't even see them in the end...but their flavor helped. The leftovers were even better.

text:
Very Good! I made it in the oven according to the foot note, however, the 4 1/2 cups of broth is too much. I had some dry stuffing mix (about 2 cups) in the pantry, so I mixed it into the stuffing to help absorb some of the liquid, then put it back in the over for 15 to 20 minutes. The final product came out great and my family loved (we didn't have any left overs). The next time I make it I will only use about 3 1/2 cups of broth (which is two 14 oz cans of broth). Thanks for submitting this recipe. It brought back memories of when my mom made suffing when I was little.

text:
This recipe is good but I'm very glad I read some of the other reviews. I like stuffing to be moist and 2 1/2 - 3 cups of liquid was just right for me. I cooked on high for the first 45 mins and turned to low for 5 hours, stirring once after 2-3 hours. It seemed overcooked to me. I think next time I'll do 30 mins on high and 3 hours on low. I think with some changes this could be a 4 star recipe. I'm only giving it a 3 as is.

text:
I love this recipe. Traditional sage stuffing is my favorite on Thanksgiving and this fits the bill.  I made it again today and received many great reviews including my niece whispering to her mom "mom, this is the best stuffing I have ever had!". I would recommend adding the chicken broth only as needed and removing the cover if it is too wet.  Otherwise, we have raised the bar for Thanksgiving stuffing.  Also, cooking this in the slow cooker makes the process so much simpler than traditional preparation.  We had extra room in our oven and it was easy to make double the recipe!

The recipe is absolutely delicious (after 4 hrs.), but please do not make the mistake I did.  Because it called for a 4-8 hr. cooking time, I thought I had better cook it for the full time.  When I checked it at about 4 hrs. it looked great and ready to use, but I wasn't sure it had cooked all the way thru, so I did the full 8.  Dried and overcooked!  Will surely make again and only cook 4 hrs. next time.  I added cooked sausage, apples , and craisins to mine and it was wonderful.    Didn't give it 5 stars because the instructions left that big window of time.

This is similar to another recipe on here that I have been using for years....It is fabulous, and a clever way to make use of a portable cooking device. text:
Another new hit on our Thanksgiving table!!  Like some other reviewers, I also assembled this the night before.  I used two packages of the store-bought sage and onion dressing, omitted the eggs, sage and mushrooms, added dried cranberries, and ended up using more than the stated amount of broth.  This cooked up perfectly in my slow cooker and everyone went back for seconds.  This will be my standard stuffing recipe from now on.  Thanks so much for posting this recipe!

text:
Very easy to make, I followed the previous ratings' advice and used only 2.5 cups of broth, and put a dish towel under the crock pot lid to curb water from the condensation from getting back into the stuffing.  That said, it still was really moist (almost a tad too moist, but some might say that would give it a more "inside the bird" texture) but tasted great.  A definate make again!

text:
I have always used my grandma's recipe for stuffing because it was the best I'd ever eaten.  I assumed this stuffing would taste pretty much the same because it had the same basic ingredients.  Well, I was wrong!!  This stuffing was way better than grandma's (sorry, Grandma).  This was even using store-brand stuffing mix instead of homemade cornbread mixed with sliced bread like grandma used.  It was so moist and the flavor was outstanding.  I left out the mushrooms since my husband doesn't like them.  Even he thought it was fantastic!!  This recipe has made me fall in love with my slow cooker again!  Thanks, Gayle!

I made this for Thanksgiving and couldn't have been more pleased. My mother-in-law took frequent tastes as it cooked and absolutely raved over how much it resembled her mom's stuffing.

One word of caution though: watch the last bit of the cooking time. I should have removed this from the crock pot about half an hour earlier than I did and it had gone from perfection to slightly soggy. Still tasted wonderful though!

text:
I just tried this tonight after reading the past reviews.  I lowered the chicken broth to about 2 cups and a few hours into the cooking time the stuffing looked great.  I knew that the recipe said to cook longer, so I left the crock pot on and watched a movie.  When I got back upstairs, the stuffing was RUINED!  It was gloppy and burnt and looked like pureed baby food!  I just got back from the store and will try this same recipe tomorrow (THANKSGIVING DAY 2007)since it tasted great in the middle of the cooking process.  I will post an update after Turkey Day to let you know how it turned out. UPDATE NOV 22, 2007:  Tried again today.  Turned out GREAT!  Used just half of the broth, only warmed it up in the crock pot and then let it sit until an hour before dinner and then turned it back on low heat.  It was perfect!  The trick is: don't stir too long, use all the broth or let sit on heat too long and it won't turn to moosh.  Will definately make again next year!

Rating:
5

2007-11-21T19:17:02.56

text:
I just tried this tonight after reading the past reviews.  I lowered the chicken broth to about 2 cups and a few hours into the cooking time the stuffing looked great.  I knew that the recipe said to cook longer, so I left the crock pot on and watched a movie.  When I got back upstairs, the stuffing was RUINED!  It was gloppy and burnt and looked like pureed baby food!  I just got back from the store and will try this same recipe tomorrow (THANKSGIVING DAY 2007)since it tasted great in the middle of the cooking process.  I will post an update after Turkey Day to let you know how it turned out. UPDATE NOV 22, 2007:  Tried again today.  Turned out GREAT!  Used just half of the broth, only warmed it up in the crock pot and then let it sit until an hour before dinner and then turned it back on low heat.  It was perfect!  The trick is: don't stir too long, use all the broth or let sit on heat too long and it won't turn to moosh.  Will definately make again next year!

Excellent! I cubed a loaf of white bread a couple of days ahead and left it on a cookie sheet in the oven to dry out. The day of my dinner, I cooked the vegetables for about ten minutes. I did use 2 packages of sliced mushrooms(16 ounces) but more importantly ONLY 2& 3/4 cups of chicken broth instead of the amount called for in the original recipe. I also accidently left the slow cooker on high for an hour, but we all know how forgiving they are! There was absolutely no need to add any liquid at the end-it was ready to serve at my convenience, after a total of about 6 hours.

text:
Hubby wanted cornbread stuffing & I wanted the ease of thsi recipe...so we made up six pkgs of cornbread & baked them in 2 jelly roll pans; then I cut them into little cubes & baked at 300 degrees until they were nice & dry. (maybe a bit too dry...we had to add even more than the 4 1/2 cups of broth LOL). Added more broth & "flipped" teh stuffing over when necessary...then took the lid off the crockpot about an hour before we served dinner. I wouldn't say the texture was excellent on this stuffing but it wasn't soggy either. Will make again...thanks Gayle Wagner!

text:
Update - made it again for T day and it was just as good as I remembered!!  I used french toast bread cubed and toasted this year w/ corn bread and did not have to add extra broth. This rocked!  I used 1 pan of corn bread, 4 big french rolls (cut into big chunks) that were toasted/stale and some apple chicken sausage.  I reserved 3 cups for the bird and it was much better out of the crock pot.  I mixed it every hour or so and used 1 small can of chicken broth thr. out cooking (which ended up being 7 or so hours).  The stuffing is done earlier than stated but the longer it cooks the more flavor it has and it browns.  I'll never put it in the oven again! I can't forget chestnuts next time. Thank you 8 - )

My son thought it was the best stuffing we've ever had for Thanksgiving.  He's a good cook himself and I appreciated the compliment.  A guest also enjoyed it.  I did make a couple of changes though in preparation on Thanksgiving by only using two cans ( 14 oz each ) of chicken broth and  adding one pound of Jimmy Dean Pork Sausage ( which was cooked first ).  I thank your reviewers with these ideas.  Next time though I will either reduce the time in the crockpot ( it seems to get darker the longer it cooks )or try baking it in the oven.  Overall still a tasty recipe although aesthetically there was room for improvement.

text:
This is a staple at holiday dinners now. It isn't much different than the stuffing I used to put in the bird, but I never thought to add egg as a binder or to toss it in the crock pot. It is lovely, because everyone is happy - there is crispy stuffing on the outside for those who like that and moister stuffing inside for the others. I also like to substitute and equal amount of the dried bread crumbs for a crumbled pan of Jiffy corn bread.  I think it adds a little more flavor.

text:
I've made this two years in a row for my office party - everyone loves it.  The texture is a little like bread pudding, but the flavor is what everyone loves.  I've found the best bread cubes to use is a mixture of white, wheat, & pumpernickel.  I substitute garlic powder for poultry seasoning and rosemary for marjoram.  Also, I use the broth sparingly.

None
text:
This was a really convenient way to free up the stove when doing an elaborate meal such as Thanksgiving. I didn't have 12 ounces of mushrooms so I used 7 ounces of Shitake mushrooms. That gave it a great and unique flavor. I also made my own bread cubes by letting fresh cubed bread sit out overnight and then lightly drying them out in the oven for maybe 10-15 mins. Everyone really liked the stuffing a lot. I think 8 hours was too long though, because at the end the stuffing was beginning to slightly burn on the bottom. I would definitely make this dish again.

This truly is the most flavorful stuffing I've ever tasted.  The flavors blended beautifully - the amount of herbs were just perfect with the right balance.. yum.. VERY tasty! My only "complaint" - would be that although the stuffing is moist, it was a little too moist to the point of that it was mushy. Next time, I'll just add enough broth to cover and gage it as it cooks. It's very simple to make and again, PACKED with flavor.

text:
I made this for Thanksgiving for the first time because we go to a football game right in the middle of the day and this recipe was so convenient for the timing. It made it so easy, because I chopped everything up the day before and measured my spices so all I had to do before I left for the game was throw it in the crock pot and mix it up. When we got back from the game, the house smelled wonderful! And the taste was awesome! I had added too much broth so I added some Stove Top chicken stuffing to get it to the right consistency. Next time I will make sure I have that on hand again as it is great insurance in case I get too crazy with the broth. This is a tasty and easy recipe. Thanks!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/18.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I agree with the last reviewer, you really need to judge the amount of broth as you're mixing up the dressing.  Based on other reviews (which varied from using no broth at all, to using the max amount), I started with none and ended up adding about 3/4 cup.  My crock pot runs hot, too, so I cooked this on low heat for 4 hours.  It was actually done in about 3 hours (maybe earlier), and I should have stirred it occasionally because the edges were a little burned.  But the smell was amazing, and the flavor was beautiful!  I don't like chunks of celery and onions, so I pureed them, with no problems.  This is now my permanent stuffing recipe -- everyone loves it, and with some preparation it only takes 5 minutes to throw together on Thanksgiving morning!

text:
Awesome Recipe! I used a variety of french bread cubes, corn bread, and white loaf bread cubes and added sage sausage.  As with any stuffing recipe, you need to judge the amount of broth needed as you mix it all up.  Mine was the right consistency going into the crock pot and perfect coming out.  I got rave reviews and it was an added bonus to be able to make it the night before, place in refrigerator, pop it in the crock pot first thing in the morning and have my oven available for everything else!  This will be my recipe for now on.  Thank you Gayle!

text:
I made this recipe in 2001, loved it, used other recipes since and have come back to this one. Look no further. I made it again this year (2009) and my family raved. My kids asked for seconds, my sister-in-law who eats like a bird couldn't stop eating it and my dad said it reminded him of the stuffing that his mom and aunt used to make. What a compliment. The only changes I made were adding about 2 cloves of minced garlic, an additional loaf of white bread that I toasted in the oven and then cut into cubes. Start with around 2 cups of broth and work your way up to your desired consistency. I ended up using about 4.5 cups. I made mine the night before and then set the slow cooker on low for about 4.5 hours. It was perfect. I think this recipe is going to be my yearly standard.

Needed a recipe for a company pot luck this week.  This is quite similar to my traditional stuffing recipe.  I normally use pork sausage for my family but because we have non pork eaters at work, I omitted it. I added 3 shredded carrots that  I sautéed with the onions. Great method when you want stuffing but you’re not cooking the turkey!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG !!!!  This recipe was DELICIOUS and has FINALLY freed up my stove burners for Thanksgiving dinner, as well as makes the stuffing in advance so that I can enjoy the Holidays socializing with my guests drinking a glass of wine before dinner (rather than making last-minute stuffing)!!  I simplified the recipe even more,,,,, I put 1 and 1/2 cubes of butter (6 oz) into a skillet and melted it on low; I added one cup of chopped celery and one cup of diced onions and simmered them until the onions became translucent in color.  Dump the butter, celery, and onions into a greased slow cooker.  Add one 12 oz box of Mrs. Cubbison's Traditional Stuffing Bread Mix into the slow cooker and lightly toss until all of the butter, onions, and celery are mixed and absorbed.  Then add a third of a can of Swanson's Chicken Broth (14.5 oz can) over the mixture and stir until just barely moist (with no liquid standing on the bottom of the crock pot).  Lightly whip 1 - 2 eggs, and pour over stuffing.  Mix until moist.  Cook on low (or "slow cook") for 4 hours, adding a drizzle or so more chicken broth every hour as needed to get the right moist consistency.  This was the HIT of Thanksgiving and everyone went back for seconds and third helpings !!!!  This recipe is a life saver !!!!!!  (I ended up using a total of about 12 oz of the can of 14.5 oz can of chicken broth after adding some each hour of cooking),,,,, just be certain NOT to put the whole can in at the beginning of the recipe because you

text:
It was pretty good! A few more fresh herbs added at the end, and maybe a little bit of fresh minced celery, would add a little bit of fresher flavor and crunch, but I'll definitely make this again. I did omit the mushrooms (on purpose) and the eggs (accidentally). I used the bagged dried-out bread cubes that my grocery store sells, and those were dry enough to need a full 4 cups of liquid. I did layer the cubes, butter/onion/celery/herb mix, and stock so that they didn't need as much mixing to come together. It's also important to note that if you're cooking this for more than 4 hours, you'll want to scrape down the sides periodically or they will burn. Ah - and also butter the *heck* out of the crock pot, to make the sides scrape down easier.

This was delicious and my family loved it, especially my husband. I excluded the mushrooms because some in the family won’t eat them, but I added preshredded (then I chopped) carrots which added texture and color. 
I used crouton style bread cubes to which I added about 3 cups total broth, starting out with 2 cups, then added some after  45 minutes on high. 
The stuffing was actually ready after 2 hours on low so I’m not sure why it states 4 -8 hours. Maybe my low setting on my Crock Pot  is hotter than others. I kept it on keep warm until dinner was served.

text:
I have made this every year and it is always a big hit. I will caution you to use the broth SPARINGLY! The first time I tried it, I was pouring on the broth and realized it was too much. I now just mix everything without it, then put in crockpot and pour about 1/2 cup of broth and stir. Add in more broth as needed and during the cooking to keep it the moisture level you prefer.

text:
Excellent nosh! I’ve never been a lover of stuffing but the hubby is so I wanted to make the effort to make him something amazing not just the boxed variety. With my prime rib in the oven I needed a slow cooker recipe and this worked beautifully! Here’s the tips ans trickes that worked for me:

Follow the recipe exactly. It says ADD BROTH UNTIL MOIST. Don’t just go all gung hoe on it. I used the Peppridge Farm cubes (2 bags) and I used 2 cups of broth. The bread cubes turned out perfectly moist and fluffy!! So instead of blaming your failed cooking on the recipe remember this tip: it’s always easier to add than take away!

text:
FIRST:  For all those claiming this ruined their holiday meal, READ the directions!  It clearly says that the amount of broth should be to wet the mixture and NOT using the whole amount.

MOST IMPORTANT:  The flavor is amazing!  I did put too much broth in myself, but added some bread and soaked out some juice while it was cooking.  My mom usually makes her homemade, Southern recipe.  She was SUPER impressed with the flavor.  And, my picky eaters that don't like mushrooms ate it and enjoyed it as well!  We're making again for the holidays!!!

text:
This was the best stuffing I've ever had outside of a turkey.  If you want you could use the turkey giblets to make a turkey stock instead of chicken broth.  I didn't, but it's an idea.  I may try it next year.  I think I used 3 cups of broth, when it started to build up liquid around the edges I stopped pouring.  The key is the type of bread.  Plain white bread isn't going to work well.  Use French or Italian bread.  Our grocery store sells bags of stale bread cubes for stuffing.  This stuffing doesn't look like Stove Top with nice little cubes, it's more of a mush style like you'd find in the turkey.  I'll make it every year and if the family ever wants stuffing randomly throughout the year, this is the recipe I'll turn to!

userID:
12074653
Display Name:
Teanut

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great.

Every year for the juiciest turkey, I spatchcock it. If you have never tried that before, I highly recommend. Unfortunately, butterflying one's turkey isn't in the cavity stuffing friendly.

I simmer the spine along with the neck and any other bits I have cut from my bird. This makes a nice low salt broth to make my crockpot stuffing. It also allows you to take advantage of some of the rendered turkey fat which is what has always made in the bird stuffing so delicious. When assembled, I put those meaty pieces in the crockpot with the stuffing as well. Leaving them on top so not to worry about leaving bits of bone in the final product. 

Use your judgement on salt. If you are using a high sodium pre-packaged broth and complain it's salty, leave your complaints at the door. That's right, it's your own fault.  

Different types of bread, cut differently and packaged bread cubes will require different amounts of moisture. Add a bit, stir, let it absorb for a while and adjust accordingly.  You won't have bread soup if you are paying attention. If you are using pre-seasoned stuffing omit the seasoning and use the recipe on the package as a guide on how much moisture you will require. As with most recipes, look at it as a general guide accepting there will always be local product variables to afford a little tweaking. Additionally, slow cookers do vary, if you managed to burn it perhaps yours cooks hotter than most. Keep an eye on your food, especially when tr

text:
I made this for Christmas dinner.  I never seem to have enough stuffing so I thought I'd give this a try even though I was skeptical. It was delicious! I only gave it 4 stars as I thought the seasoning was a little on the light side so I did add more.  I hate when people tweak a recipe and then give it a 5 star.  Anyway, I added just enough chicken stock to moisten then added a bit throughout the day.  For the people that complained that their dinner was ruined because it was too much broth.......just read the  recipe!  It gives you an amount to have at the ready but CLEARLY  says add enough broth to moisten!  It's really common sense to not soak it in broth.  Anyway, I was pleasantly surprised how well this turned out and will do this again for extra stuffing!  Really wish I had a liner though, tough to clean the crock after making this.

I tried this  because we were having a large group of friends for Christmas lunch and limited oven space.  It is easy to prepare.  I cooked it for four hours on low after the initial 45 minutes on high.  As not all of our friends like mushrooms, I left those out.

text:
Based on other  comments, I used barely 2 cups of broth. I also browned some sausage and added that .  I used fresh bread which I cut into cubes. While the bread was still soft I added all the seasonings, then spread them across cookie sheets and put them in the 225 degree oven about 10-15 minutes. I didn't let them completely brown as I did not want them as dry as the packaged stuffing mixes. I also did this the night before. This recipe turned out  great!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this stuffing two years in a row now, and it's gotten nothing but rave reviews from everyone - even those who claim they "hate" stuffing. I love how using the crockpot will free up precious oven space for other dishes! 

I've followed the recipe very closely both times. I usually prep everything in the crockpot the night before EXCEPT the broth and eggs. In the morning, I add the beaten eggs and broth (and yes, please listen to all the reviews that say to ADD IT SLOWLY, cup at a time, until it's well moistened - some may not need the entire 4 cups, although I certainly did!), and with plastic gloves on, I work all the liquid through the breadcrumbs and veggies. 

Cook on low for 4 hours and you've got perfectly moistened, perfectly seasoned stuffing with minimal work. THANK YOU for a fabulous keeper of a recipe!!

text:
I made this in the oven and use the oven directions provided below. When I made it, I only used two cups of chicken broth, and it was plenty. I always use one and a half loaves of white bread that I toast in the oven to make the dressing. It tastes even better in the oven than it does from the crockpot! No other changes are necessary.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was quite good!  I used veggie broth so I could eat it too (vegetarian) and added garlic to the sauté.  Did not add all the broth, started slowly just to moisten and added as I checked throughout the cook.  I did not start on high, due to other reviews, rather cooked from 11:30 till about 4:00 on low and it cooked a bit much for my taste, so next time I will start it later.  I used Pepperidge Farm boxed stuffing mix and added a few sprigs of chopped fresh poultry herbs to the mix.  Also, as I added the broth, I did as others suggested and placed a clean dish towel under the crock lid to soak up extra moisture.  Thank you so much for the recipe and all the previous reviews, combined with my own very minor tweaks, this was a great stuffing that left open the oven and stovetop!

text:
Tasty traditional dressing. We freeze nice leftover breads throughout the year so our dressing includes white, wheat, grain, rye, etc.  I also save plenty of turkey stock so we use that in place of chicken. Before serving we put ours in a foil pan under the broiler for several minutes to get a crusty top. Very good stuff!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-11-29T10:55:37.76
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4827241
Display Name:
Terry L. Novack
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1752958.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this and it is slow cooking. I make this recipe every Thanksgiving and am always so happy to find it every time I Google it. I wrote a review years ago but not sure where it is. This dish is hands down the favorite dish of ALL dishes on the table. Mashed potatoes and homemade gravy comes in second. First I would like to say that I am surprised the author has not adjusted the chicken broth measurement. In my opinion it is clearly way off. I adjusted it to 2 cups to start and then I watch and drizzle as needed. I peek and stir every 30 minutes or so. I like mushrooms but NOT in stuffing so I leave them out. I use an entire loaf of sliced sourdough bread. I put the slices on a huge platter, cover with paper towels and put in the oven with the oven OFF overnight. In the morning I tear all the slices into small/med pieces. I do start the slow cooker on high to get it going and then turn it down to low. I personally like it on the tender/soggy side. It tastes like it came out of the bird with none of the hassle and potential danger of baking the stuffing in the bird. This recipe is a keeper. I bought a portable GE slow cooker (the cord coils in and disappears) which is awesome. And the lid locks for travel.  You will need a large slow cooker for this recipe. I wish I had this recipe decades ago. You can whip this out very quickly the morning of Thanksgiving. And the best part is that it is delicious. And of course that it does not require an oven to bake!  Thanks!

None
text:
I htink this recipe calls for wayyyy too much broth. I added two cups and it became somewhat mushy. Add only one cup to start off. Use your judgement as it keeps cookin if you need to add more. If you do so, slowly add a tiny bit at a time. If it becomes mushy here is how it can be saved. Keep off crockpot lid for about an hour to give juices time to evaporate. Sprinkle in bread crumbs until it gets back to a good consistency.

text:
Great with my changes ;) me and my family like a sweet corn tasting stuffing. Made 5 changes.
1) used betty crocker cornbread packets (2) adding 4tbsp of sugar, for the bread once baked addef to croc pot crumbled.
2) adjusted the recipe to half.
3) added 1/2 cup of frozrn corn
4) added only 1 cup of water no chicken broth
5) did not add egg
Sauteeted veggies add spices a plenty and kept on warm did not really need to cook to much plus my croc gets very hot.

text:
This was a major hit at Thanksgiving!! I got many compliments! If your stuffing is too soggy you are adding too much broth, be sure to only mix the broth as needed till bread crumbs are "moistened". I used prepackaged bread crumbs and corn bread crumbs and it was fantastic! Always do a trial run of any recipe before serving it for a big shindig so that you know what to do next time you make it :)

Simply fantastic!  Make sure to be very careful when adding the chicken broth to just add enough to dampen the bread and other ingredients.  This is important because juices from the celery and other ingredients will come out during cooking.  So delicious!!!

text:
First off I used half of the butter. It was plenty. I omitted the herbs and spices in lieu of already seasoned bread crumbs. I used 2 cans of chicken broth, (about 4 C.)and cooked it as directed, on high for 45 min. low 4 hrs. (I didn't open it once!) I was skeptical, but this was fantastic! Moist, but not soggy. I will most definitely be making this again at Christmas. OH! And next year I'll be sure to make it veggie broth so the vegetarians can eat it!!

This was so good but I added some things too it.  I browned up pork sage sausage, added 2 apples and about 3/4c of dried cranberries.   It was moist and I used all of the chx stock.  The only thing I would caution people about is that you can't leave it in the crockpot on low all day, the bottom scorched.  Otherwise, an excellent basic recipe!

text:
This was so good but I added some things too it.  I browned up pork sage sausage, added 2 apples and about 3/4c of dried cranberries.   It was moist and I used all of the chx stock.  The only thing I would caution people about is that you can't leave it in the crockpot on low all day, the bottom scorched.  Otherwise, an excellent basic recipe!

text:
I would give 2.5 stars if I could. 

The taste of the recipe seems to be good. However, this recipe turned out quite soggy and mushy. Furthermore, the amounts listed do not yield 16 servings...unless each person takes a tablespoon of stuffing. After 8 hours in my slow cooker, what looked like a decent amount of stuffing for my company potluck (we have about 50 people in my office) reduced down to serve MAYBE a family of 5-6 people. I had to supplement our entree order with stuffing to make sure people actually get to enjoy some with our Thanksgiving-themed potluck.

I think that this may have turned out better if I had cooked it on low for only 4 hours and was able to babysit and stir it often. To be able to bring it to our company potluck, I threw everything in for the night so it was unattended most of the 8 hours of low cooking time. This resulted in it being mostly mushy and soggy, but also scorched on the sides and bottom. 

Oh, and as for my adjustments: I didn't use the full amount of broth (I followed the instructions and I don't understand why so many people couldn't read that it states to use just enough to moisten) and skipped on the mushrooms.

country:
None
text:
As others have noted, DON'T ADD ALL 4-1/2 CUPS CHICKEN BROTH initially. While the recipe does read "pour in enough broth to moisten," it doesn't make it clear that the cook should be prepared to add broth as the slow cooker dries out the mixture over the cooking time. There was a full two cups of leftover chicken broth when I prepared this dressing. The volume of chicken broth required will vary depending on the type of bread used, and the length of actual cooking time. My version was still a little moist (though my wife said she prefers dressing like that). I prefer dressing that is not so moist. The cook can--of course--control the moisture content by adding the volume of chicken broth that suits their preferences.

This had the taste and texture of being cooked inside the bird! (moist and gooey, in a good way) I started with 2 boxes of Mrs. Cubbison's Herb Seasoned stuffing (16 cups). This seemed to work fine - it cooked for a total of about 5 hours.

text:
Used this recipe for our Thanksgiving stuffing recipe - worked perfectly!  I followed another reviewers advice and cooked some sage sausage to add, then just added a sprinkle of sage to the mix.  I was nervous about the chicken broth so I decided to follow previous reviews and add slowly, as needed.  I ended up using a little over 4 cups.  I agree that the chicken broth amount has to do with the type of breadcrumbs used.  I used the original dried stuffing cubes, and added 2 cups at a time, mixing as I added.  For the crockpot, after the 45 minutes on high, I had on low for about 6 hours- it turned out great!  Stuffing was moist and fluffy, but not too much.  Plus the sausage added the perfect little kick that it needed.  I'm definitely keeping this recipe for next Thanksgiving!

My familys favorite! I omit the eggs and make this the night before. Yesterday I re-moistened with some chicken broth and transferred to my slow cooker....started on low and turned to warm stirring every so often to ensure no sticking. I also spray my insert with a little non cooking spray to also ensure no sticking. Its a perfect tasting recipe and the slow cooker method to keeping it hot and moist .....well for me there is no other way. Second year in a row making this and will continue to do so...one less dish to re-heat in the oven. Thanks!

Terrific! My husband said it was the best I'd ever made. I used only 2.5 cups of broth & used the rest from the 32 oz. container with the gravy package that came with the Jenny-O turkey instead of water. Highlly recommend the Rosemary Roasted Turkey, too!

text:
This was excellent stuffing.  I made french bread the day before, cut it up and stored it in the oven, cubed it and followed the directions in the recipe, minus the egg.  I was leary of the liquid amount so I started with half and added as it cooked.  I think I probably used the full amount.  I had to take some stuffing out and put it in a bowl then put it back in to shuffle it around while it cooked so it was cooked evenly.  I got many compliments on it at Thanksgiving.  It's a much easier way to cook stuffing.  There are even crispy crusty spots on the sides and bottom if you cook it long enough.

text:
This is a SUPER EASY, Great tasting recipe.  I was looking for a very moist, sticky consistancy recipe for stuffing.  This was perfect!  I used approximately 4 cups of broth and it was great.  My recommendation would be to add the broth slowly...how much you need is a personal preference.  We left the mushrooms out for the picky eaters in the family and it was great.  Ours sat in the crock pot for a good 7 hours, but it was ready to go after about 4.5 hours.  This is a keeper!

text:
I made this for Thanksgiving today and it was a big hit.  I did make a few changes just to suit our preferences.  1) I halved the recipe to fit in our medium sized crockpot.  2) I added browned sausage and sauteed the veggies in the drippings 3) I omitted the seasoning since the pepperidge farm corn bread stuffing I used  was already seasoned (I did add about 1 tsp black pepper and 1 tsp creole seasoning) 4) I used 1 1/2 cans of chicken broth.  I started the crockpot out on high as directed for the first 45 minutes.  It then cooked an additional 5 hours.   I did notice the stuffing was looking a little soggy, so I took the lid off for the last 45 minutes of cook time and it was perfect.  Will DEFINITELY be making this again.....

text:
I've made this recipe for years and just made it again :) Happy Thanksgiving! I thought I'd share my modifications. Make sure you use a really dense bread like ciabatta bread and make sure it's really dry. I like to add a 1/2 cup of currants to it and about 2 cups of cooked sausage with sage. I never need as much chicken broth as it calls for, so add it slowly-not all at once. This is a great recipe and frees up your oven of other things on turkey day!

userID:
1769334
Display Name:
ChowHound
isPro:

followersCount:
2

27

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/176750.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an easy recipe to prep the day before. In the weeks leading up to Thanksgiving I started buying stale loaves of herb bread from the grocery store's "Reduced for Quick Sale" rack.  I stored the bread in the freezer and took them out 2 days ahead to thaw/dry out.  I followed the recipe pretty well for the most part (I added chopped carrots for added veggies), and found the amount of broth to be just right for my mixture.  I pretty much filled the entire crock pot with bread...then as it cooked midway through, I dumped the rest of the bread in (I had enough broth to ad-lib if I needed to).    The stuffing tasted wonderful!  It is moist, just like we like it.  It went well with our turkey gravy.  It is even better the day after (and after)!  My husband says the flavors are better than the boxed stuffing.  This is definitely a keeper in my family.
Review:
Rating:

text:
This was very good.  I actually adjusted it to make it lower calorie. Instead of butter i used 2 tbsp garlic canola oil and about 1 cup vegetable broth.  I did not use fresh parsley or mushrooms, but I did use dried parsley.  I used a combo of country white bread, sourdough, and multi grain.  I actually used closer to 15 cups of bread crumbs, which fit in my slow cooker fine.  I probably did use close to the 4 cups of broth.  I just added enough to moisten the bread, and checked and added more about every hour.  I cooked on low for about 4 hours.  It would have been very good with something sweet- apples or cranberries.  It was really good anyways.  Great and easy recipe!

text:
I read multiple reviews but none saying they used cornbread vs. bread.  I prefer cornbread, so decided to go ahead and make my own cornbread like I usually do and then go with the remainng ingredients because I thought the spices and other ingredients sounded like a great combination.  I was not disappointed - the flavor combo was awesome. My hubby doesn't "like" mushrooms, so I chopped them up small and he never even knew they were in there, but they added wonderful flavor.  Also, I opted to cook in the oven as an alternative.  Definitely a keeper recipe.  I will make it again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2669313.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have served this stuffing at the last 3 Thanksgivings that I have hosted. Its a fantastic way to make stuffing and not take up any more stove space. I do add some sage sausage, I give the sliced mushrooms a rough chop and like the other reviews I cut the chicken broth in half. I start with just adding 2 cups, if its still really dry I add a bit more and after cooking half way I take a quick taste and maybe add more if needed. My crock pot cooks really fast so I cook it on low for 2 hours.

I used about 3 cups of the broth.  I will definitely make this again for next Thanksgiving.

text:
This is my go-to recipe. I've made it multiple times, and it's turned out great each time. I leave off the poultry seasoning & mushrooms because I hate both of those things (besides, the sage, thyme, and marjoram are basically poultry seasoning) and substitute vegetable stock for the chicken (have a few veg heads in my acquaintance). I cook it in the oven in a 9x13 pan with the full quantity of broth with no problems.

text:
I just finished making this and tasted it - awesome!  The flavor was so good.  In the past the stuffings I've made have been bland.  I used two 10 oz boxes of stuffing - they say it's 16 cups.  I made giblet stuffing so I boiled the giblets and chopped them up and used the liquid for the broth, it was about 4 cups.  I added the entire amount because it was just moist and I used the paper towel trick.  I remove the paper towel just before I turned the crockpot to warm because it might start to dry out.  My 8 year old daughter tasted it and said she was in heaven.

In my crock I used 2 cups of broth, 1/2 cup butter, fresh herbs and omitted the marjoram.  I cooked on low for 4 hours and removed the lid for the last 30 min.  This is a great recipe, but you must use stale bread!  I have tried this in the oven and was dissappointed; it was soggy throughout and never set.

country:
None
text:
Dry out the bread (12 cups = 1 loaf, I used 1/2 brown & 1/2 cinammon rasin) for at lease 3 days. Cooked down the celery & onion in LOTS of butter.  It looks like too much butter - but you'll use less chicken stock.  I used less than half the required chicken stock and still found it too wet.  Cooked without the lid on for the entire time and it was a little less wet by the time I served it.  Mom & mom-in-law both LOVED it.  They've both asked for the recipe!  SCORE!

text:
I made this for Thanksgiving this year and it was great!  Frees up room in the oven and is simple.  I read all the reviews before making it and was a little nervous that it wouldn't turn out right.  Depending on how you like your stuffing, use the broth sparingly.  My family likes stuffing a little on the dry side, so I only used about 2 cups and it was still pretty moist.  I plan to try it again and maybe add some oysters too.  Thanks!

I was looking for a nice recipe for dressing to take to a work luncheon this week.  I tested it over the weekend and am I glad I did.  This dressing was swimming in butter.  It had a gummy, mushy, and sticky consistency.  I followed the directions and only changed the amount of broth at the advice of reviews to be sure I didn't use too much. 

The taste wasn't bad but I would never serve this to anyone.  I was really disappointed.  I WANTED to love this.

text:
I thought this recipe was extremely helpful that you can assemble the ingredients and throw it in the crockpot.  The only downfall was that I had used herb-seasoned bread cubes so when I had added all the seasonings from the recipe to the bread, it came out extremely salty.  I had to add more bread cubes and then use water not chicken stock to cut all the saltiness. That was my fault though! So just keep that in mind when using already seasoned bread! Other than that, the stuffing came out moist but not to moist at all.  In fact, the stuffing that was on the bottom and sides of the crockpot was crispy.  Loved it though!

country:
None
text:
I used 3 bags of the M. Cubisons seasoned stuffing, I substituted chopped carrots for the mushrooms (preference), substituted 1 cup of orange juice for broth and omitted the marjoram (after reading other comments) kept everything else the same- slow cooked low for about 3 1/2 hrs then upped it to high for 1 hour. This is a "wet" stuffing- I like "wet" but most of my friends like a more crusty fluffy stuffing. Next time I will use a little less broth, or add the 4th bag of stuffing cubes and fluff the stuffing a little more.  I will make this again- easier to use the crock pot for sure!!!

text:
Wonderful idea that I'll use every year from now on! So nice to not have the stuffing to worry about. My only problem was that I didn't read the reviews (I was rushing around too much I guess :)) Anyway, IMO it doesn't need the high heat setting for the first 45 min. Mine ended up being very dark brown, basically burnt, along the outside, and that was after just 4 hours. The inside stuffing was perfect, thankfully. Next time I'll just keep the crockpot set at low the whole time. Also, I agree with the reviewer who said that if you're using the commercial stuffing cubes, like Peppridge Farm, you'll need more chicken stock. Fresh bread cubes need less liquid. I used Peppridge Farm and ended up adding about 3 c. of stock. Again, thanks so much for this keeper!

text:
okay, I've made this two years in a row for Thanksgiving Day and both times it has been a hit!  This year however, I forgot to add the egg before it started cooking but no worries!  It was fixed by just adding more broth...in fact, I didn't even realize I had forgotten the egg until the next day when I was putting the recipe copy away!  I let it cook for about 3.5-4 hours...no more time is needed.  Next time I make it I will add raisins and maybe some chestnuts...this recipe is a keeper! Who doesn't love saving oven space, not to mention time, on such a busy day!?

None
country:
None
text:
EXCELLENT FLAVOR but beware of how much broth to use.  The recipe calls for 4.5C of chicken broth but the directions say pour broth over stuffing mixture until moist.  You could use 2C and be just fine.  You can always add more near the end if you need to but I'd find it hard to believe that you would.  Also, the condensation from the lid on the crockpot adds moisture.  The flavor is awesome, the recipe is easy.  I will make this every year but use 2C of broth or less.

text:
This was just terrific.  I didn't add the mushrooms, and I didn't find that this was too wet. I am thinking maybe some of the problems other reviewers had with the stuffing being too wet (and thus having to add less broth) might be because of all the extra liquid the mushrooms would add.  I did the recipe exactly as written with the exception of not adding mushrooms.  I cooked it in the slow cooker for about 8 hours; I could've served it much sooner however because it was 'done' at probably 4-5 hours - those extra few hours just allowed it to get deeper in color, maybe a little mushier and the edges crisped up a bit.  Good stuff, would definitely do this again, absolutely.

ANASTASIAJANE

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I think I've finally nailed this recipe after making it for the 4th time:  DOUBLE the amount of bread (get 2 large French loaves & measure out 24 cups); use 3 eggs; skip the separate spices and just use 3 T. of poultry seasoning; DON'T USE MORE THAN 2 CUPS of broth (start w/ 1 1/2 cups); keep amounts of butter, onion, celery, parsley & black pepper the same; omit the salt entirely; DON'T COOK ON HIGH FIRST or the bottom will get hard and crusty (we actually ate this part because it tasted good but it's not really what you want) and the middle will be mushy.  This will not take 8 hours to cook; give it about 2.  Leftovers are very tasty.
Review:

text:
Great recipe!  It got rave reviews from family members who have never had stuffing made outside the bird!!  And it was so easy to make.  I threw the bread, (I used French Bread) sauted onions, celery, parsley, and seasonings together the night before in a large bowl (did not use mushrooms).  Then the next morning I put everything in the crock pot.  I added about 2 cups broth and that was plenty.  I omitted the eggs....After about 2 hours cooking on low, it was done. It was wet, but not  mushy so I just kept the lid off for a while.  Using French bread definately helped it keep shape better.  Everyone was asking for the recipe!  This is a keeper.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe! The only addition I made was adding cranraisins and a chopped apple but I wouldn't change the spices, they were right on.  I only added 3 1/2 to 4 cups of turkey stock and that was perfect. Stiring every hour was a real help, well folding it, unless you like mush that is.  Taking off the lid the last 1 to 2 to dry out the stuffing really worked well.  Infact we served 14 guest and there were no leftovers! No complaints and a favorite of many.
This is a keeper. Thanks for sharing it, I will never do stuffing any other way and this was my first time using the  crock pot for stuffing.

text:
I made this last year, and had never made stuffing in my life. Everyone loved it, and it was so easy! I use the hard store bought bread crumbs, and start out with less than 4 cups of chicken broth. You can always add more as you're cooking. I cut up the onion and celery the night before and put in fridge so the next morning all I have to do is mix the ingredients and put in the crockpot. Definitely a time saver when you need the oven for everything else. I came back for the recipe this year. Both times I have not had to cook more than 4 hours before it is ready.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4604447.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good, and nice because it took care of the stuffing without the use of the oven.  I used 1 cube salted, one cube unsalted butter and low-sodium broth.  I omitted the salt, but later tasted it and added a few sprinkles.  I also omitted the mushrooms and eggs.  I only used 1 cup of broth.  That was plenty for me.  I was worried it would be soggy but it wasn't- use 1 cup of broth and then go from there- you may not need anymore.  The texture of this stuffing is pretty moist; similar to that of stuffing that is cooked inside a turkey as opposed to just in a dish in the oven.    I used a mix of wheat bread and sourdough; let it dry out overnight.  I think it could use a little more of the herbs- season to taste.

text:
My husband likes his stuffing very moist and he said this is the best I have ever made - we have been married over 40 years!!  The only spices I used were sage and poultry seasoning and no mushrooms.  I started with 1 1/2 cans of chicken broth (14 oz. size) and added the rest gradually when I stirred the stuffing every hour or so. Started it on high for 45 min. and then 4 hours was perfect.  It was a big hit, and I will definitely use it again.  I also liked the convenience of preparation in the crockpot.  Thanks.

Awesome Stuffing Recipie!!!  This was the first time I made a "Home Made" stuffing and not from the box it was EXCEPTIONALLY good!!!  The flavoring was superb!!!  The only thing i would change is either HALF the brooth or DOUBLE the bread cubes because i only used 2 cans of the 3 needed and it was VERY VERY moist, almost TOO moist but still quite YUMMY!!! LOTS of prep work envolved and i would say takes closer to 45 min. to cut vegies/bread if your doing alone but well worth the work!!!  YUM YUM!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Interesting dish. 
I was confused on how to do the bread cubes- but I got a loaf of white bread, toasted and then let it sit out for 45 mins. Then I pinched off pieces into a big bowl. When I put the veggies on top of the bread- I put in all the butter. I'm not sure if this is how it's supposed to go, but the final dressing was very buttery. Omit to taste. I only used a can and a half of broth (prob. b/c of butter). And put it in the crock pot. It seemed to be done sooner and then transfered over to a dish and put it in the oven til dinner time.
It turned out really good- and everyone raved about it... even my sister who doesn't like dressing. I, however, have smelled it all day, so I wasn't very hungry for it. 
Good dish, and will be a classic from now on. Thanks

I will just get in line behind the other wonderful reviews. I use Pepperidge Farm stuffing instead of bread crumbs, omit the mushrooms but add some garlic and a bit more onion. This tasted so good.  For my first time cooking the holiday dinner I was extremely nervous, but I always have luck with the slow cooker.  This was so helpful for freeing up the stovetop, and it tasted better than any stuffing I've had.  My guests were impressed.  I was able to start this the night before Christmas and it cooked for a total of about 12-14 hours, it was extremely wet, so I had to add quite a bit more bread crumbs, but the flavor was excellent!  Thanks!

text:
I made this recipe last year with the dry bread cubes and it was really good, but, I love homemade cornbread dressing.  This year I made the Easy Corn Bread recipe, on the back of the Quaker yellow corn meal cannister, the night before.  The next day I mixed everything together adding a little extra poultry seasoning and 1 1/2 cups broth. Later I added the rest of the broth from the can because I didn't want to waste it. I cooked on low about 5 hrs, leaving the lid off at times so it would cook quicker.  Great flavor!  Thanks!

I did not think this recipe was any better than Stove Top.  I halved the recipe, but you cannot cut the cooking time in half.  Cooking it for 3 hours on low was too long and about a third of the way through the stuffing began to burn and stick to the sides of the slow cooker.  I substituted vegetable broth instead of chicken broth and left out the mushrooms. The only good thing about this recipe is you don't have to use up oven space.

text:
This recipe was just fabulous!I will never cook it the traditional way again. It is a simple,easy-to-find ingredients, you throw it all in the crockpot and VOILA! Heavenly stuffing-seasoned just perfect! And the best part(besides the eating)is that it frees up precious space in your oven-while that turkey/chicken is cooking. 
I did make a small change,however. I used half the butter and every few hours I'd throw in a half-cup more chicken broth to keep it moist. And even though I put this puppy to cook at 8:30 AM, it was still deliciously moist when we served supper at 5:PM. I'm going to make this often, scaling down the recipe for our single family size-it reheats fine the next day too!

text:
This stuffing came out just right texture and tasted great. I made my own bread cubes and probably used just about the entire 4 cups of broth. From reading other reviews, it seems that if you use the dehydrated pre-made bread cubes, you probably need less broth. Anyway, I started out by adding about 2 1/2 cups of broth and added additional broth at times to keep it moist but not mushy. Be SURE to stir it at least every hour or so to keep it from sticking to the sides of the crock pot.

userID:
943369
Display Name:
Cinnamon Lover
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1745519.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Imagine the joy when I discovered a Thanksgiving staple that practically cooked itself! Since we're frying our turkey this year, there had to be an alternative to the usual stuffing method. With the tight rotation scheduled for the oven, I was pleased to find this recipe. As I was cooking the initial ingredients, I could tell this one was going to tasty.  And since I put it in at 3am, I awoke to the most divine aroma that so appropriately ushered in the holiday. I've been a bit concerned that my crockpot cooks pretty hot even on low and this experience confirmed it. 8 hours in my crock was far too long as all the edges browned and hardened.  I should have probably cut that in half. Also, while the flavor was incredible, the consistency left a lot to be desired.  It was mushy...very mushy; the bread cubes having lost all their form and just melded together in a vaguely glue-like fashion. Yuck! Ergo, I believe next time I will reduce the broth by at least half and (as others have suggested) add broth during the cooking process as needed.  So, I give this recipe 4 stars for wonderful flavor and ease of preparation, but deduct a star for recipe amounts and directions. I do recommend this recipe, although with the above caveats.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2003-11-27T18:30:47.81
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
18131839
Display Name:
Christiane Clermont
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4

favoritesCount:
65

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3634274.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this recipe for Thanksgiving today )11/27/03) and it was very good.  I don't really agree with the other reviews that the amount of broth or stock is too much - the reason it calls for so much is because it's supposed to cook for almost 8 hours!  If you didn't have all that moisture, by the end of 8 hours, it would be too dry.  And if this came out burned like someone said, then the crockpot must not have been turned down to the low setting, or they didn't put enough stock in.  The only complaint I have is that mine came out a little salty, and I think that it was from the broth that I used.  Be careful with store bought chicken stock - you never really know how salty it is, because it varies from container to container.  Overall, a pretty good recipe.

text:
My husband was very skeptical about this.  He normally makes the stuffing but I wanted to try something different since some of my family members do not like soggy stuffing or from the turkey.  It turned out wonderful!  I did not need the entire amount of broth.  I used a packaged stuffing mix and cooked it for about 2 hours.  Every half hour I would add about a 1/2 cup of stuffing mix plus a tablespoon of liguid so it would not be soggy or too firm.  My stepfather who hates stuffing actually went back for a second helping.

text:
This was good. I usually cook my stuffing inside the bird so this alternative when not cooking the whole bird. I started this before work and let it go the full 8 hours. I don't think that you need to put it on high at the beginning if you plan on the longer cooking time. I did cook up pound of Jimmy Dean sausage and added it too. I also added 2 tsp of garlic to the vegetable mixture. I also agree with other reviewers concerning the amount of broth depending on the type of bread cubes that you use. I used packed very dry bread cubes so I did need all of the broth. We love mushrooms so I may increase the amount next time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am giving this 5 stars because I think the basic recipe and concept deserve it.  However, I think preparing it as directed was a mistake.

Having read several of the reviews, I paid attention to type of bread and the amount of chicken stock used.  I had a drier-style sourdough bread, and the amount of stock was appropriate for it.

My slow cooker tends to cook somewhat hot, even on the Low setting, and this may have skewed the results somewhat.  I cooked it for 4 hours on Low, without a starting High setting phase, and it came out rather over-cooked (to the point where the bread was breaking down--dissolving is too strong a term, but you get my meaning).  I was checking /stirring every hour, and about the 2 hour point would have been perfect.

All this having been said, the balance of flavors was excellent, and with the adjustments I think are needed, will make an excellent dish.

text:
I read quite a few reviews and took the advice of not using as much broth. I actually didn't measure the broth but added throughout the cooking as needed.  Also, I used a tea towel to absorb the condensation so the stuffing didn't  get to mushy.  I stirred the stuffing and switched out the tea towel every hour.  (only used two towels as one dried while the other was absorbing).  I dried my own bread crumbs for a few days, which I think makes a difference.  You really can tweak this recipes to your own liking.  By adding ingredients or omitting to suit your own tastes.  I used less poultry seasoning and added pork sausage, shredded carrots and turkey drippings.  Everyone loved it!!

text:
This is sooo good. I’ve made it in the camper and every time it comes out perfect.  As everyone noted, only add enough liquid to wet the mixture, watch it closely and add more as needed. I use the seasoned, dried bread crumbs (Mrs. Cubbisons) so add less of the fresh herbs.  Also, make sure you turn it down after 45 mins or it will dry up and burn. Love this recipe!
