Great solution for cooking Thanksgiving without needing to use the oven.  I used chicken sausage due to guests who don't eat pork, but I think it would be much tastier with Italian pork sausage.  Hot tip from other reviewers:  Go light on the liquid and put a clean cotton towel on top of the stuffing, then put the lid on the slow cooker.  This keeps it from getting to moist from the condensation.

This would not have been edible had I not removed it from the crock pot and cooked it in the oven to finish it off.  I would definitely cut the butter quantity in half as it was really greasy (and that was impossible to cook out in the oven).   I used a little less chicken broth than it called for and it was too wet after several hours in the crock pot and some of it got too brown on the bottom in the crock pot.   I would try again but use a lot less butter and less spices and plan for time to finish in the oven.

userID:
5158799
Display Name:
Mcochrane
isPro:

1
favoritesCount:
12
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It’s a great way to make stuffing and I will definitely do it this way again. I took the suggestion of the towel under the lid, which makes sense because you don’t want that extra liquid dripping into your stuffing. I could only find the hard seasoned cubed bread crumbs, so I cut back on the sage, thyme and salt. I took the suggestions of only starting with half the broth. I checked it after two hours to stir and added more broth as needed. After that I checked hourly,  stirring and adding more broth the longer it cooked. Mine was perfect after  4-5 hours. I wouldn’t recommend cooking it longer, it  will just make it cook down and intensify your seasoning.  I found this out the hard way after having to keep it warm for an additional 2 hours  unexpectedly.  Overall great recipe.

Made it according to the reviews using half the broth at first. It was still too soupy. I took it out after several hours & placed it in a casserole dish in the oven. I baked it at 350 degrees for about 20 minutes. It was much better as far as moisture, & the taste is fabulous. I think I'll just make it in the oven next time.

country:
None
text:
I made it for a work pot-luck - it was great! I was curious how it would work. I added, dried 1/2 cup dried cranberries,  (1 lb of COOKED sage sausage and 1 cup walnuts....including recipies the celery and onion and mushrooms. I also added spices sage, rosemary, and thyme, salt and pepper.  I also used a mix of cornbread and seasoned bread crumbs by pepperidge farm.  BEST ADVICE add the stock 1.5 cups ONLY and after 2 hrs and right before serving add more only as needed. This method of cooking, free's you from using the oven, but you still have to WATCH IT. The 45 minutes on high, is so you achieve SOME of that oven TOASTED effect, so I suggest you DONT SKIP this 1st step, or do it at least half of the time suggested, if possible.  But just know, you should be checking this once an hour.

This was a huge hit for Thanksgiving.  The only thing I changed was I used celery and carrots instead of onions and mushrooms.  I only used 2 cups of broth and put a cloth over the cover to help with condensation.  I used Sara Lee Artesano golden wheat bread.  I used almost one loaf and the bread is a very thick sliced bread and it worked wonderfully.  I don't like my stuffing soft and mushy so I stayed away from white bread.

text:
Excellent recipe and loved that it didn't take up valuable oven space on Thanksgiving.  Following the recipe closely, I only added enough broth to moisten the bread cubes then I checked on the stuffing every hour and added more broth if needed.  One thing---even on low this recipe took only about 3.5 hours to cook so watch for burning if you plan to cook longer.

text:
I’ve been hosting thanksgiving for years, and my dear mother raised me well, teaching me all the tricks of prepping such meals. But using this recipe as my main model earned me serious kudos this year. As in, “This was the best thanksgiving meal I’ve ever had” kudos. From my picky husband of 17 years. 

So, it’s  a keeper.  Skip the mushrooms. YUCK. Add another couple cups of chopped apples for sweetness and go easy on the broth, adding as needed. And if you’re in a rush, use the packet of seasoning in the breadcrumb package. 

And this isn’t stuffing. It’s dressing.

text:
Great traditional stuffing  (aka dressing) recipe. I didn't change a thing and found that I did need all of that broth. The amount of liquid you use will depend on how toasted or dry your bread is, so add it gradually until you get the desired amount of moisture. I actually make this the day before so it is ready to cook on Thanksgiving.

text:
Crock pot dressing is a life saver on Thanksgiving Day.  I am giving this recipe  4 stars because I haven't made it yet, but have had this type of dressing.  Place a towel over the top of the crock pot, THEN the lid.  This will prevent the moisture from being absorbed by the dressing. I also use the crock pot liners which make for easy clean up.

Display Name:
Nina Jensen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5317030.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this! I read through a lot of the comments below and found a technique that made this the easiest side dish for any holiday occasion. 

First off, I used dried French bread from my local bakery. it was not very hard therefore I only used about 2 cups of chicken broth. Secondly, I made this the night before and let it sit overnight. then as I put the turkey in the oven, I put the stuffing on low for about 4 hours. I did not add the mushrooms. I did however add breakfast sausage the morning of. thirdly, I would stir the stuffing every 25 minutes as well as basting the turkey. Kept it nice and fluffy. I did however notice it was getting a tad soggy due to the steam, therefore I opened the cover for the last hour. It turned out beautifully.

text:
Perfect stuffing every year for Thanksgiving! Love the method of using the slow cooker because it saves me space in the oven for other dishes. I omit the mushrooms only because my husband hates them. Sometimes I use vegetable broth or turkey broth in place of chicken broth. Just follow the recipe steps. Only add enough broth in the beginning to moisten the mixture, and then add additional broth as needed during the rest of the cooking. I check and stir the stuffing about every hour, adding additional broth if I need to.

country:
None
text:
This is a very satisfying, easy dressing recipe.  I used local store brand stuffing (about 15 oz - a bag and a half).  It took all of the broth and could have used 1/2-1 c. more I think.  Leftovers were pretty dry.  I don't really understand putting it on high for 45 minutes.  Next time I will just keep it on low for 4 hours, stirring every hour.  Also, if I used just one bag of stuffing, then I would decrease the vegetables by 1/2 cup, but leave the herbs the same.  I used a small can of mushroom pieces and stems and that was plenty.  Overall a great recipe, just needs tweaking per personal preference.  I will make it again!

text:
I have made this recipe multiple times.  I have learned a couple of things.  First, my family likes herb-y dressing and I have started using packaged herb-flavored stuffing along with the prescribed seasoning instead of plain stuffing.  It is perfect for us.  I also cut back on the initial chicken  broth and added it to mix as the day went along.  Finally, once the eggs are cooked, this can be moved to "warm" and stirred occasionally.  It is a forgiving recipe.

text:
Big hit on Thanksgiving - even with those not crazy about stuffing! I made it day before as others suggested except for the egg which I added next day. Also added only 2-2  1/2cups of broth on first day - just enough to moisten. Next day added more broth - just enough to get desired moisture. I did place towel on top after cooking for awhile as suggested. I halved the recipe with no problems. Delicious.

text:
I make this stuffing recipe every Thanksgiving as it is easy to prepare and keep warm in the crock pot.  As many have already stated, you need to eyeball the amount of broth.  If in doubt, err on the side of dry (about 2-2.5 cups) and you can add more broth as you go along.  Check on it frequently.  The flavor is amazing....my family asks for it every year.

text:
This one is a keeper! I made it for Thanksgiving and everyone loved it. I made sure to read all the reviews first and was sure to use the tea towel under the lid;  intermittently add enough broth to moisten it (4 cups); stirred frequently. Note: My mom has Celiac so I used Gluten Free Herb & Garlic croutons. It turned out great but was rather expensive. Next time I'll buy the GF bread and give it  a few days to dry out.

text:
Great recipe, it turned out wonderfully and everyone loved it!

I used store-bought dried bread and 4 cups of broth instead of 4.5. It was still a tad  too moist at the end, but I just left the lid off the slow cooker while I finished the rest of my preparations and it ended up being perfect.

I used veggie stock for this recipe and skipped the poultry seasoning, so that my vegetarian wife would be able to eat it. I'd recommend this recipe to anyone!

text:
I'm going to try this recipe again, because I think it has great potential, but I'll make some major changes.  One, the bread cubes.  I used real bread and cubed it.  I'll lay the bread out on a flat surface the night before to allow it to thoroughly dry out.  I'll also cut the butter down to 1/4 cup.  One cup of butter for this recipe is way too much.  I don't know how much broth I'll end up using.  When I used 1 cup of butter, I didn't use any broth, and it still came out too moist and mushy.  It tasted good (how can anything taste bad with that much butter!), but it looked disgusting.

text:
This stuffing is good, one thing though that I didn't see in the other reviews is that you need to stir the stuffing every hour or so.  Otherwise the stuffing that touches the sides of the slow cooker dries out and gets crusty.  Maybe that's obvious to everyone else but I didn't stir it and the sides kind of burnt.

text:
Made this yesterday for the first time.  Omitted the mushrooms and added a pound of sage pork sausage.  Also sprayed the crock pot with Pam before transferring to the crockpot. Checked it about every hour, added some broth as needed and stirred.  Used most of the chicken broth over the course of cooking time.  Turned out much better than the stuffing I baked last year probably because other side dishes required different oven temps.  Made ours in a larger slow cooker and was ready in 4 1/2 to 5 hours.  Was so nice not to have a crowded oven!  Husband said to print that recipe!  A definite keeper!

text:
I was really nervous to try this for Thanksgiving with a house full but after reading many reviews I felt I had enough information to give it a shot. I was so glad I did! I followed the advice of adding just enough broth at first to moisten and adding a little at a time throughout the cooking process.  I did not turn it on high for the first hour as  the recipe said. It cooked for appx. 4.5 - 5 hrs on low, stirring every hour and adding a little broth. I used a total of 2.5 cups of broth. The only change I made was add 6 oz  of cooked chestnuts and a tablespoon of sage and thyme. I didn't have poultry seasoning but the dried bread cubes were already seasoned. It turned out great and everyone loved it. It was so easy and  I will now do this every year. Loved having the extra room in the oven!

text:
This is my family's favorite  and I make it every year but do not use the amount of chicken broth as stated! I use enough to only moisten (approx. 1 cup)  the mixture & I add 1 pk of Jimmy Dean or Bob Evans  sausage,  browned & drained .  I also use the seasoned bread cubes (not soft) slow cook until sides start to get brown (appox 6 hrs) turn off & leave covered to stay warm. Everyone raves!

text:
I've never made or liked stuffing before. But I was hosting a friendsgiving and knew I had to make it or else my dinner would be incomplete. This stuff is AMAZING. I was intimidating at first by all the spices because I didn't have most of them so I had to go and buy them. I'm glad I did!! The spices definitely made the taste. I followed the recipe almost to a tee with even weighing out the amount of mushrooms. What I did slightly differently was that I used $2 baguette bread from the store (so I didn't have to worry about drying out  my own white bread) and I used, at most, 1.5 cups of chicken broth for 8 servings. I probably could have done less too. Maybe 1.25 cups. Also listened to what other reviewers said and skipped the 45min on high and just did 4 hr on low. It was delicious.

Display Name:
West Coast Cook
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After inviting family and friends for Canadian Thanksgiving on the second Monday in October I began thinking about Thanksgiving dinners from my childhood. In the last few years my sister has hosted this event and it is her way or the highway on cooking the turkey and making the dressing. As I was channelling the scents and flavours of my late mother's dinners I checked out the online recipes and found this one for a slow cooker dressing. The ingredients were familiar and comfortable, the method simple if it worked. Thanks to the hundreds of reviews I read I began to see the possible difficulties and used many of the reviewers suggestions to good effect. I want to thank everyone for submitting their reviews. They were most helpful and I was entranced by the peek into so many interesting Thanksgiving experiences.
 I decided to make twice the recipe as leftovers and care packages for the guests were an important consideration. I began with 4 loaves of artisan Levain bread with a heavy crust which has a strong sourdough texture, but not taste, for holding up in a dressing. I added two loaves of a white French sourdough. I air dried them for 4 days with the crusts cut off.  They were hand pulled into chunks for 3 of the 4 days then into torn into dressing size pieces for the final day before assembling. The bread was dry but not hard like commercial bread cubes or croutons. 
On preparing the onions, celery, parsley and mushrooms I used my Cuisinart to chop fine but not puree each

text:
Made this for Thanksgiving dinner, and we all loved it! I only used 1 tsp of salt, and I followed ChefNan's review, and I just set the crock pot on low for 4 hours (skipped the HIGH setting part). The sides were a little well done for our liking at 4 hours, but the majority of it was great! The spices and vegetable amounts were perfect! One of my little nieces is gluten-sensitive, so I made a gluten-free version, using a combination of GF bread cubes that I found at Whole Foods (in the freezer case), and some toasted bread cubes from some GF cornbread that I had previously made. I used the whole 4 1/2 cups broth, and added 1/2 cup more broth, because we like a more moist stuffing. It was so nice not to have to think about this side, but just to let it do its thing! This was great, and it would probably be awesome with sausage in it, I'll have to try that next year. I am saving it as my go-to stuffing recipe (GF or not)! Thank you!

text:
This recipe is great and no, the amount of broth isn't a misprint. I definitely agree that it probably depends on the breadcrumbs you're using. I used two boxes of the Mrs. Cubbison's bread crumbs and that works out fine with the 4 cups of broth. I found that laying a dish towel on top of the stuffing under the lid is necessary. I also took another reviewer's suggestion of stirring every hour. This is a wonderful recipe. **
**Made this again for Thanksgiving this year. This time I made my own breadcrumbs and definitely didn't use as much broth. Just added enough until the breadcrumbs were moistened and stirred every 1/2 hour or so.

Tried this today.  Followed advice of others and added broth a bit at a time.  Sprayed the crock-pot first to keep it from sticking.  Just low -sodium broth to start, then later on added turkey broth from cooking the gizzard and neck.  Chopped up the gizzard and liver and stirred it into the stuffing and added a handful of chopped walnuts per another reviewer. Stirred it several times and kept adding broth to my preference.   It was delicious and the smell was out of this world when you took the top off.  A definite keeper!

text:
I made it exactly as written except for the marjoram (didn't have any) and used about 3 1/2-4 cups of chicken broth and 3 bags of Pepperidge Farms seasoned cubed stuffing. It was perfect. If you use homemade bread cubes I can see how you would need less broth but the bagged cubes need more moisture. The reviewers that had problems were probably using softer bread. I'll be making this every Thanksgiving :)

text:
I mixed cornbread and herb dry stuffing; using almost 48 ounces of low sodium chicken broth to keep it from drying out.  I also did stir at least every 60-90 minutes and only cooked on high for four hours.  Within an hour of dinner service I lined a pan with cranberry sauce placed the stuffing on top and left it in the oven on 350 degrees.  The next time I make it, I'll be more experimental leaving out the mushrooms, adding raisins or nuts and not adding any extra sodium since the chicken broth has salt in it as well.

text:
Great way to free up oven space on Thanksgiving. I have used this recipe for 2 years now and have found the amount of broth is really best to eyeball it. I start it with 2 cups then check it a couple times throughout cooking and add when needed. Generally use about 2.5-3.5 cups. Only giving 4 stars because I think this recipe as is, is a great base recipe but could use additional ingredients to kick it up to 5 stars. I will try adding sausage and more variety of seasonings next time.

text:
I really liked how this stuffing turned out.  It was easy and saved us from an over crowded oven.  I did not use the eggs.  I did not do the 45 minutes on high.  I took the advice of other reviewers and just moistened the stuffing with broth when I mixed it and then kept moistening it as it cooked. The stuffing was kind of fluffy and very moist.  If you want a drier dressing I would do the 45 minutes on high and add less broth as you go.  The flavor was great.

text:
This stuffing turned out really good.  I used vegetable stock instead of chicken since i'm a vegetarian, and also omitted the egg due to my nephews food allergies.  I used dried bread cubes and around 3 cups of stock total.  Just one word of caution, I kept an eye on the stuffing, stirring every hour or so to bring the wet ingredients to the top.  But then I had to go out for about 2 hours, and when I came back, the stuffing had really cooked down and turned dark brown.  Still tasted good, but I would have probably turned the cooker off sooner had I been watching it.  Overall a keeper recipe!

I think 4 hours was a bit too long to cook the stuffing. Had I trusted my instincts and stopped at 3 hours then I'm sure I would have loved it and graded it with 5 stars, but I stuck to my rule of never tweaking a recipe on the first try. It tasted a bit overcooked and the bread crumbs turned into mush even though I only used not even half of the broth this recipe called for. I'll try again next time and cook it for less time and hopefully it'll be a hit.

Full disclosure - I didn't follow this to the tee. I did do the basic gist of it and it turned out GREAT! Everyone loved it and I'll be doing this again. So nice that it doesn't take up the oven. Highly recommend using a slow cooker bag for easy clean-up.
Modifications: I used about 2 1/3 cups of broth, forgot to buy fresh parsley so skipped that, did the herb pack that came with my bread cubes instead (just easier). Just use as much broth as needed to moisten it all nicely.

text:
Worked Great!  This was a hit at my office potluck.  We had 25 eaters, and though not everyone ate stuffing, I had a tiny bit leftover after making 24 servings.  I used 1.5 tubes of Jimmy Dean Sage sausage (had it in the fridge) and only a small amount of actual sage.  Also, I got a loaf of White Mountain Bread and a loaf of French, and it worked beautifully.  The bread completely filled my 6q crock pot so the early stages of cooking was a little dicey but it cooked down nicely.  I ended up using about 2 3/4 C of chicken broth.

text:
This recipe was amazing!! Easy and oh so yummy!! I used two loaves of gluten free bread from Schar. I put it in my food processor to chop it up and it worked like a charm. I used about two cups of gluten free reduced sodium chicken broth and I put a towel under the lid to absorb the moisture. I cooked it on low for six hours. I will never make stuffing any other way now that I have been spoiled with this recipe!! I left out the mushrooms as the kiddos are not a fan. Try this recipe... it will not disappoint!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a family Christmas supper. My Mother always added brown sugar to her stuffing and I have been trying to duplicate the flavour that everyone in my family grew up with and misses since my Mom passed away. This recipe was close to hers so I omitted the mushrooms, thyme, and marjoram and added about a 1/4 cup brown sugar to the cooked vegetables and let it cook down. My siblings and my mom's grandchildren all loved the taste and said that it reminded them of Mom/Grandma. I found it was way too much broth and so it was gummy and today when I make it I will use way less. I am going to try stuffing my chicken with it today so wish me luck!! Thanx for the memory evoking recipe.

2 main points: I did not cook it on high for 45 minutes and I prepared the mix (minus the beaten eggs and the broth) the night before, which I enjoyed. I had to work on TG day at 7am and cooked it in my crock pot at work.  
 I woke up and added the beaten eggs and enough broth to moisten the mixture before I left the house and brought extra broth to moisten as needed.  I only ended up adding a few splashes of broth while cooking but I did need to stir it frequently.  I noticed that although it LOOKED like it might be soggy, it was actually very fluffy and a great texture.  I only gave 4 stars because I had to stir it so frequently to prevent it from burning, and I only cooked it on low for less than 4 hours.  Everyone said it was great1

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was great, you just have to tailor it to match what type of bread you are using (per other people's suggestions).  I used the store bought dried stuffing mix and used less than 4 cups of broth; just pour in enough to moisten the bread, no more.  I actually substituted veggie broth to make it vegetarian.  If you buy the seasoned stuffing, you probably don't need to add all of the spices, just be aware so you stuffing isnt over seasoned.  I cooked the celery, onion, and thyme in the butter then just mixed everything in the slow cooker and turned it on low for ~5 hours.  I added diced green apples and a splash of broth every so often, stirring it.  Came out perfect!

Just made this again today, and it was utterly delicious!!  Instead of the dried seasonings/herbs, I used fresh minced thyme and sage (those plastic clamshell fresh herbs available in every grocery store), and substituted granulated chicken bouillon for the salt.  I prepared it all yesterday, stored it in the crockpot in the fridge and then cooked it today on "high" for 2 hours before serving -- perfection.  My family ADORES this recipe (heck, they ask for it in July)!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My mom and I both made this last Thanksgiving and had the same results:  OK flavor but NOT a time saver!  You have to stir it every half hour or so, and you'll check it much more often than that. We both decided it was done [different slow cookers and elevations] at 6 hours which may help those who would like a tighter window than "4-8 hours" when planning their cooking timeline. Regular stuffing/dressing cooked in a casserole dish just goes into the oven, and out again in under an hour.  A slow cooker cannot produce the evenly crispy brown loveliness on top and solid warmth throughout you get from baking dressing in the oven; some parts charred, some parts were a little gooey, despite our attentive babysitting.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THIS IS EXCELLENT!!!  I followed the recipe to a T, taking note that the chicken broth is a variant ingredient.  I had two 32 oz boxes of broth and wound up using only about half of one box (2 C) if not a little less.  I used a slightly moister bread cube (not like a crouton dry type) and  I cooked mine for aprox 4 hrs, left the lid off for about the last 20 min and it was perfect.  I think if you use a more dry bread cube you will need more chicken broth, regardless add a little at a time as it is easier to add liquid than take it away.  I also had extra bread cubes on hand so if it was too moist i could add some more bread as this would help "take away" some liquid.  I had people who don't generally eat stuffing trying this at our Thanksgiving dinner and LOVING it!  I even got requested to make it for Christmas dinner.  The only complaint i have about this stuffing is that there wasn't any left over.

text:
Thank you, Gayle! I grew up with and LOVED my Grandma's basic dressing/stuffing recipe. However, since she cooked by memory, we wrote down the ingredients but not the measurements. However....and thankfully so....your recipe was very much like hers, complete with measurements. And I made the "oven version". THANK YOU....my dressing turned out just like my Grandma's! :) :)

ps...I've tinkered with the recipe, since then. I cut down on the celery (about 2 stalks), the sage, and just dried-out then ripped up one loaf of white bread. However, I'm still VERY grateful to you Gayle because this recipe (which I bake, BTW) is just like my Grandma's.  Thank you for reviving the wonderful memories. :)

country:
None
text:
Perfect first time on Thanksgiving!  I omitted the mushrooms and substituted about 1/4 cup raisins (both at my mother's suggestion).  I had left my bread open in a bowl on the counter for 2 days, but it was still soft in places.  Therefore, I needed only about 2 cups of broth.  I added broth and stirred until each piece of bread was moist, but not soaked.  I cooked it on high for 1/2 hour, then on low for 4 hours, stirring about 3 times total.  I suggest using a quality crock pot.  It had a wonderful flavor, texture, and color.  My husband repeated that he doesn't like stuffing but he really likes this!

text:
Loved this stuffing.  I used low sodium chicken stock and ended up adding all the salt back in, FYI!  Needed more pepper than suggested as well.  Use FRESH herbs- it makes all the difference! Rated it four stars instead of 5 because with only 4 cups of chicken stock, the stuffing became soggy in the crock pot so I transferred the stuffing into a 9 x 13 pan and baked uncovered for 30 minutes to dry it out, a bit.  (Kind of defeats the purpose of a crock pot recipe.)  But I will definitely make again, just because it is SO EASY!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I am giving it 5 stars because when all was said and done, it got rave reviews. I made it ahead as suggested by another reviewer. I added the broth little by little until I got the consistancy I wanted before adding all to the slow cooker. I checked after and few hours and it was turning into a soggy mess when I stirred it. I tried covering the top with foil, but that did not seem to help. I saved it by putting the lid on cross-ways and letting alot of air into it, stirring often. It dried out perfectly and was a hit. In the future, I will start out with the lid askew and adjust as needed. The flavors were great! Having limited oven and counter space, I had the crockpot in the laundry room out of the way and it worked perfectly. I will fix my stuffing this way from now on.

text:
Loved this stuffing....I did increase the spices to our liking....and loved the mushrooms in this. The key to this recipe is to keep stirring and "fluffing" this stuffing every hour or so. Ours was perfect, not gummy or solid like other reviewers had said. I also added the chicken broth as needed, so it was not over mushy. Perfect and stayed nice and hot and loved the whole crockpot aspect. Will most def. make again! Delicious!

text:
Just served this for Thanksgiving dinner and it was a hit! Loved the fact that it freed up space in the oven. Also, since I didn't stuff the turkey, it cooked faster and the meal was done in no time.  I also agree with the "too much liquid" comments. I started with 2C of broth, and added as I went along. At one point (about 4C's) the stuffing was a little too moist, so I just added a few more handfuls of stuffing mix and cooked it for the last hour with the lid off. PERFECT!

text:
Loved this old-fashioned stuffing recipe. It has been years since I have made dressing like this and it was my favorite part of Thanksgiving. I only used 1/2 c. of butter, 3 c. ck broth, no mushrooms. I added 2 peeled & diced apples to the celery/onions and 3/4 c. of raisins to the stuffing. I had left over homemade bun in the freezer that I used for the bread cubes and it worked nice.  I doubled the seasoning but not the salt. It was perfect.  No leftovers though. The crock pot worked perfect and nice not to need more oven space.  It was moist and not dry. Yum.

country:

text:
Fantastic stuffing recipe! Our guest that was bringing the stuffing this year begged off at the last minute, and I was in a quandry on when I would make the stuffing. This recipe came to the rescue! I cut and prepped the veggies the night before, and cubed up some French bread loves to dry overnight. Thanksgiving morning, the bread cubes got a bit of oven warming/cooling time between the pumpkin pie, which crisped them up great. I only used the 2 c. of chicken broth, which was plenty. But do stir the stuffing at least once an hour. I also took the lid off for the last 30 minutes (cooked it for the 45 min. on high and about 4.5 hr on low). And don't leave out the mushrooms, they really add to the recipe (and easy enough to pick out/eat around if someone doesn't like 'em).

Super wonderful. Made it on Thanksgiving Day for my first time hosting the family. It's a mix in the family--meat-eaters, vegetarian, and vegan. We made this vegan. We did put a bit too much broth in--took the lid off for a while in the midst of the day to let some of the moisture steam off. It was a little mushy (me and my vegan sis like it that way) but turned out great. Very flavorful. Made the house smell great right from the go. My sister is going to replace her vegan mushroom dressing with this recipe. Awesome.

text:
I mixed this up the night before minus the eggs.  I used a bag of croutons, I chopped up some rosemary, sage and thyme.  I used a teaspoon of poultry season.  I used only 2 cups of broth for overnight.  The rest was the same.  Then the day of I mixed in the eggs and two more cups broth.  I had to add a little more broth during cooking.  It was perfect.  I did cook the gizzards and heart of the turkey with the stuffing, but it was oh so good!

text:
I had to search for this recipe so I could make it tomorrow.  My Grandma has been making this stuffing for over 40 years and it is a family favorite.  I cannot imagine Thanksgiving without it.  She uses store bought bread crumbs in a bag, so it in neccessary to use at least 3 cups of broth.  I can see that if your bread is not extremely dry the broth would be overdone.  This is the best stuffing in the world!!

WAFFELZ

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/49136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Success on my first homemade stuffing attempt!!

I made this for my first time hosting family Christmas. Everyone loved it! I made the full recipe and filled two crock-pots!  
I made two loaves of homemade white bread in my bread machine. I dried it out a couple days before in my oven.I figured I got about 6 cups of cubes per loaf.
I followed the recipe and used the vegetables & spices recommended.  I used Campbell's chicken stock in the tetra pack. I think there was just shy of 4 cups in it. I added the whole thing, but did so throughout the cooking time so it was never sitting in a lot of liquid. This helped the bread from becoming too soggy. I noticed that there were a few crusty pieces in the mix, but no one complained about it. The presentation was nice & the parsley was a great touch! The flavour was excellent, and I much prefer this recipe to the Stove-Top messy mush. I will definitely make again, but probably customize it a bit to suit whatever I'm serving.

A definite keeper!
Review:

I rarely post reviews to the receipes I get on this site.  However, this one was such a success that I had to.  My husband (very very picky)said this was "the best" stuffing he has ever had.  Regarding the broth, I just added 1/2 and then added as needed, watching as the stuffing cooked. I made it for Thanksgiving and left my guests wanting more.  It's Sunday after Thansgiving and I'm making it for dinner again.  EXCELLENT!

text:
I always make chestnut stuffing, so added chestnuts to the recipe instead of the mushrooms.  I added more spices than called for as well.  The taste was good, but I'm not sure about the consistency.  I missed not having it in the turkey!  I did not turn the crockpot to high - which was a good thing, as the outside edges of the stuffing were somewhat burnt.  Just kept it on low for 4 hours.  I would make it again, but experiment with different types of breads maybe, and work on amount of liquid as well.

text:
I was making a lot of things for Thanksgiving so I needed to make some ahead of time items or I would have gone crazy. This recipe was excellent.  I pre-cooked everything the night before.  All I had to do on Thanksgiving day was toss in bread crumbs, chicken stock (I used half chicken stock/ half water b/c the prepped mix was too salty), and eggs, and put it in the slow cooker.  I also cooked some sausage with the sautee mix.  Overall, a great recipe.  I think it would have benefited from a handful of cranberries (poached in orange juice), but my husband is not a fan.

text:
I made this for Thanksgiving and it was fantastic!  I halved the recipe (except for the herbs) because I was making it for only 4 people.  I used store bought whole-grain bread, about 1 pound, that I cut up into cubes and dried out in my oven.  I left out the mushrooms, because I didn't have any.  I added diced apple, and cashews.  I would have liked to add some pork sausage -- definitely will next time.  I used a full 14 oz. can of broth at the beginning, and during the cooking added about 1/2 of a second can.  I think I will also increase the amount of poultry seasoning and other herbs next time, as the whole-grain bread has a stronger taste that overshadowed the other flavors.  This made for such an easy dinner prep!  I loved having the extra oven space!

text:
It was my first time making stuffing (*ahem* dressing), and I was pretty nervous. I found this and made it because of how many great reviews it got. I left out the mushrooms, as my hubby hates 'em, and had to use a little bit of extra powdered chicken stock as my "poultry seasoning". I only ended up using about 1 1/2 cups of the broth and it came out with some crusty and some mushy pieces... Just as it should be! I stirred it about once an hour and only cooked it on low for 3 hours. Then I turned it off until we took the Turkey out to rest at which time I put it on "keep warm". It was AWESOME! Everyone raved about it!

text:
The oven in my apartment only has one rack and I needed to bake a lot of things, so I was going to skip the stuffing until I saw this recipe.  I left out the celery because we don't like it, used half the butter and cut up 12 cups worth of bread cubes a few days ago.  Note: the bread shrinks as it dries so you'll need more than you think!  Anyway, I thought this had a really good flavor, but next time I'm going to use three eggs and only a cup and a half or so of broth, as well as half the salt and even less butter.

Too soggy for me.  I thought I screwed up and I may still have, but I read the other reviews and don't feel so bad I wasn't the only one....cause I didn't want to make as much as the recipe called for, so I tried to 1/2 it.  I probably used too much chicken broth still.  My husband loved this though.  I myself wasn't crazy about the spices.  But like I said, I "1/2'd" the recipe and I don't ever measure my spices, so I still may have used to much.  Glad I only made 1/2, there was way too much left over.
I think this recipe would be great with your own tweaking and preferences so I won't give up on it yet.  It was too easy.  LOL

text:
I'm not sure that I should review this recipe as I changed a lot - but since we did use the base I guess I will.  We used the butter, onion, parsley, bread crumbs, broth and egg.  To this we added a 1/4 c. dried cranberries, 1/4 c. diced (cooked) pork tenderloin, 1/4 c. raw cashews, 1/4 c. roasted almonds and 1 t. each Emeril's Essence, Montreal chicken seasoning, celery salt, marjoram and onion powder.  I used a mix of homemade cornbread and homemade whole wheat bread for the bread cubes.  Really, really exceptional!  Thank you for the recipe!

This recipe is so easy and tastes so wonderful! I made it last Thanksgiving and Christmas, and will use it again this year. Even members of my family who normally do not like stuffing enjoy this recipe. It is very easy to modify this and make it healthier or making it low-carb by using low carb bread instead of regular bread cubes or stuffing. It is great to be able to pop this in the crockpot in the morning and not worry about it again until dinner time. Good going, Gayle!

text:
This was pretty good.  I only used 6oz of fresh sliced mushrooms because we're not a huge fan...and next time I think I'll leave them out altogether.  If you like mushrooms, you'll probably love them in this, though (something about the texture bothers me...).  And also, 4 1/2 cups of chicken broth was DEFINITLEY too much for me...as it was, I only used about 3 and it was very soggy!  I let it air dry for about an hour while the turkey finished, and it was better...I like firmer stuffing though, so next time I won't add so much.  Very easy, though, and great flavor!!

text:
Wow!  Everyone raved about this dish at our Thanksgiving meal.  I only wish I made more.  It was so easy to prepare, and even if it took extra time and effort, the flavor of the stuffing would make up for it.  The stuffing itself took only 20-minutes to prepare, and that included cutting and sauteing the vegetables!  I also saved much needed space in the oven, and I didn't have to babysit the dish since it was in the crockpot all day.  I added exactly 2 1/4 cups of broth (as called for in the recipe) and didn't alter any of the seasonings.  The stuffing was perfect!  I plan to make this more often than just for a holiday meal.

text:
This is great and easy stuffing!  I cut the recipe in half (small group), which had me finished in about 1/2 the time with about 2 1/2 cups of broth.  I used one box of store-bought bread cubes, omitted the mushrooms, and was pretty heavy handed with the herb seasonings.  My only issue today was that it was REALLY salty in my opinion, but I think that was because of my quick and easy use of canned store-bought broth.  I would definitely buy low sodium broth next time AND leave out the salt from the recipe.  My family, however, didn't know what I was talking about it and ate almost all of it!
Thanks for this easy way to take care of one dish.

I made this for a pot luck; some people liked it and some didn't. The flavor was great, but it was really wet and almost congealed in texture. Maybe I didn't do something right? I definitely prefer a more bread-like stuffing. Oh, and as some others mentioned, there was a fair amount that was overcooked (burnt and hard) so I threw it out. I'd make it again, but bake it--which of course defeats the whole purpose of slow cooker stuffing!
